title: Leveraging Small LLMs for Argument Mining in Education: Argument Component Identification, Classification, and Assessment
author: Lucile Favero (ELLIS Alicante, Spain), Juan Antonio Pérez-Ortiz (Universitat d'Alacant, Spain), Tanja Käser (École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, EPFL, Switzerland), Nuria Oliver (ELLIS Alicante, Spain)
relevance_why: This paper explores the application of small open-source Large Language Models (LLMs) in educational settings, which could inspire similar methodologies in audio-language tasks, particularly in feedback generation for audio processing.
background: This research investigates how small models can analyze the structure of student essays, providing feedback on argument quality and structure.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel approach using small Large Language Models to perform a complete argument mining pipeline in education, achieving improved segmentation and classification accuracy for student essays.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods in argument mining primarily relied on larger, more resource-intensive models which are not practical for local deployment.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work demonstrates that smaller, open-source models can effectively manage argument mining tasks, proving that less resource-heavy solutions can achieve competitive performance.

key_innovation: The study successfully integrates few-shot prompting and fine-tuning techniques to leverage small LLMs, ensuring accessibility and privacy by enabling local execution on student devices.
real_world_impact: This research demonstrates the potential for enhancing writing skills among students through real-time feedback, improving educational outcomes while preserving data privacy.
limitations: The performance on quality assessment was notably lower than desired, indicating challenges with annotation quality.

new_terms.argument mining: **Argument mining** refers to the process of identifying, classifying, and analyzing the argumentative structure in written text.
new_terms.few-shot prompting: **Few-shot prompting** involves providing a model with few example inputs to learn how to perform a task without extensive training.

open_sourcing: The code for the research is available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/ACL_2025-45CE/
